10.text:
Tim Yeo MP:>>In 2008, Parliament passed a
new law, the Climate Change Act. This committed

16.text:
the UK to cutting greenhouse gas emissions
by at least 80% by 2050.

25.text:
A big cut in greenhouse gas emissions from the energy sector and from
electricity generation in particular is an

31.text:
essential first step towards meeting this
target. On top of this, no less than a quarter

38.text:
of our existing power stations must shut down
by the end of this decade. £100 billion of

45.text:
investment is needed to replace old polluting
power stations with cleaner low carbon energy

53.text:
sources.
The Energy and Climate Change Committee scrutinised

57.text:
the Government’s proposals right from the
start. The cheapest form of energy is the

63.text:
energy we don’t use in the first place.
Yet despite the fact that energy efficiency

68.text:
is one of the cheapest ways to cut greenhouse
gas emissions and to improve energy security

75.text:
and end fuel poverty, they were neglected
in the Government’s original proposals.

81.text:
So the Committee recommended that demand reduction
and energy efficiency be placed at the very

87.text:
heart of Electricity Market Reform.
Unfortunately today the Government is still

93.text:
putting too much emphasis on building new
electrical generating capacity, instead of

99.text:
promoting demand-side measures that would
improve security of supply and also reduce

105.text:
consumer bills. We recommended that reform
of the electricity market should be designed

111.text:
to include a target for cutting the carbon
intensity of our power system. This target

118.text:
would give investors greater certainty about
the direction of energy policy. As Chair of

124.text:
the Committee, I introduced an amendment in
the Energy Bill, which was based on the Committee’s

130.text:
recommendations. My amendment would have include
in the Bill an emissions target that would

136.text:
require power plants to cut their carbon emissions
substantially by 2030. Although this amendment

144.text:
was narrowly defeated by 23 votes, it was
one of the largest rebellions of this Parliament

151.text:
up to that point.
Our scrutiny showed that the Energy Bill as

155.text:
originally drafted actually threatened the
ability of small independent energy companies

162.text:
to compete with the Big Six. In the end the
Committee did secure important clauses in

169.text:
the Bill that allowed Government intervention
to ensure independent generators can have

175.text:
better access to the market.
The Committee’s scrutiny of the draft Energy

180.text:
Bill was widely recognised as leading to significant
improvements in the whole process of Electricity

186.text:
Market Reform. I’m sure that in the next
Parliament, the new Energy and Climate Change

191.text:
Committee will make sure that the Government
achieves this aim.
